content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: brilliant clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle on the well known heads or tails game :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good for a clash and good to understand
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
seems just the right difficulty for a clash. I think the normal ones are too easy.
It seems slightly more difficult than your typical clash, but I like it. I'm especially interested in seeing how compact some people will get their codes!
Interesting puzzle, I'll be happy to try to solve it

@Goal
"If neither Alice's nor Bob's sequence appears in the round then neither person wins.
If Alice and Bob have the same sequence and it appears in the round then both people win."

--> This should include a statement saying the order matters.
E.g. "If Alice's sequence appears before Bob's in the round then Alice wins and vice versa".
It looks like a nice clash !

# Round rules need precision

@goal section states :
"If neither Alice's nor Bob's sequence appears in the round then neither person wins. If Alice and Bob have the same sequence and it appears in the round then both people win."

--> It's not just about the sequence appearing in the round, it's about whose sequence appears first. This should be explicit in the @goal section.

Hi @Aceofsquares and thanks for your Contribution :+1: !
 -> I agree with your Job ;-) ...

Bellow my own Python 9 lines of code :
n = int(input())
sa=sb=0
for i in range(n):
 a,b,t=input().split()
 #print(i, a, b, t, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
 a=t.find(a);b=t.find(b)
 #print(a,b, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
 if(b<0 or (a>=0 and a<b)):sa+=1
 if(a<0 or (b>=0 and b<a)):sb+=1
 #print("=>",sa,sb, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
i=(sa<sb)+2*(sa==sb)
#print(i, file=sys.stderr, flush=True)
print(["Alice wins!","Bob wins!","Draw!"][i])

Interesting idea!

Title
* Why "1"?

Goal
* Last paragraph: Suggest to change "Alice or Bob sequence's" to "Alice's or Bob's sequence".

* Please mention the possibility of multiple rounds, and that the person who wins the most rounds is the overall winner.

Goal / Output
* The usual practice is to format the text you've formatted in <<bold>> as {{constants}} instead, and <<bold>> will be for formatting such things as important keywords or headings. But since the statement is clear as it is, it's also fine if you keep the current formatting.

Cases
* Bob never wins in a validator! Please swap/modify some cases to balance the wins for tests and validators separately (e.g. so that Alice wins in 3 tests and 3 validators, and Bob wins in 2 tests and 2 validators).

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write answer" or "write winner".

Thanks.

Thanks for the input.  I have made most of the changes recommended.  Will work on the tests vs. validators issue once I update my test generation script to be a bit smarter so it's not too much of a pain to generate tests.

As for the "1" in the title, I originally had another way to play the "game" but wanted to simplify it first so I added a 1 to indicate the first version of the game.

Rashiq,

    Thank you for your input.  I'm not sure I understand your concern as the first statement under the Round Rules is

"A round consists of each trying to predict a sequence of 3 coin flips that will appear before the other player's sequence of 3 coin flips. "

which includes the statement "will appear before the other player's".

Understood, thank you for your reply and follow-up!

For the tests vs validators issue, the easiest fix is to swap the test and the validator in one of the pairs where currently Bob wins the test and Alice wins the validator. That'll make Bob wins two tests and two validators, and the balance will be good enough.
